instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used to identify coumarin-based food additives?
Output: The spectrum used to identify coumarin-based food additives is terahertz (THz) absorbance spectra.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to identify coumarin-based food additives?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to identify coumarin-based food additives were principal component analysis (PCA) combined with manifold learning t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) and an improved support vector machine (SVM) model using differential evolution (DE) to improve gray wolf optimization (GWO).

instruction: What metric was chosen to identify coumarin-based food additives?
Output: The metric used to identify coumarin-based food additives was classification accuracy.

instruction: What machine learning models were used to improve the SVM model to identify coumarin-based food additives?
Output: To identify coumarin-based food additives, two machine learning models were used to improve the SVM model. These models are differential evolution (DE) and gray wolf optimization (GWO).

instruction: How does the P-t-SNE-DEGWO-SVM model compare to traditional detection methods in terms of time-saving and efficiency for identifying coumarin-based food additives using terahertz spectroscopy?
Output:
The P-t-SNE-DEGWO-SVM model proposed in the past study is more time-saving and efficient compared to traditional detection methods for identifying coumarin-based food additives using terahertz spectroscopy. The past study states that the prediction set accuracy of the P-t-SNE-DEGWO-SVM model is 98.61%, which is higher than the accuracy achieved by traditional methods. This indicates that the P-t-SNE-DEGWO-SVM model is more effective in accurately identifying coumarin-based food additives.

Additionally, the past study mentions that the P-t-SNE-DEGWO-SVM model outperforms other models, such as PCA-DEGWO-SVM and P-t-SNE-GWO-SVM, in terms of accuracy. This suggests that the P-t-SNE-DEGWO-SVM model is more reliable and efficient in identifying coumarin-based food additives.

Overall, the P-t-SNE-DEGWO-SVM model offers improved time-saving and efficiency compared to traditional detection methods, making it a valuable approach for rapid and on-site identification of various food additives, including coumarin-based additives.
